awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Gaining a molecular level understanding of the sorption of model organic molecules to engineered soil surrogates
awd_abstract_narration:
The funding of this project by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program in the Division of Chemistry will enable Professors Robert Cook and David Spivak of Louisiana State University (LSU) and Karl Mueller of Pennsylvania State University (PSU) to introduce a postdoctoral fellow, graduate students, and undergraduate students to interdisciplinary research involving organic, analytical, and environmental chemistry. Recruitment will focus on students from underrepresented groups who will be introduced to the complexity of environmental chemical issues. In his graduate-level polymer synthesis class, Professor Spivak will show how emerging methods of polymer synthesis can be used to mimic some of nature's complexity and can aid environmental chemistry. Professors Cook (LSU) and Mueller (PSU), both of whom teach senior-level environmental chemistry courses, will incorporate findings and approaches developed in this award to illustrate how fundamental chemical interactions apply to environmental systems and how they play a role in the determination of the fate and transport of anthropogenic chemicals in the environment.

This project is aimed at a molecular level understanding of how pesticides interact with soils by studying the uptake of model pesticide molecules by engineered soil surrogates (ESS). Surrogates will be synthesized by functionalizing known mineral surfaces with organic moieties of varying composition and polarity, echoing those found in real soil. Similarly, incorporating fluorinated pesticides of varied polarities and chemical compositions, in concert with a range of NMR methods, will enable molecular level characterization of the interactions. The NMR experiments will be guided and complemented by batch sorption studies, which will report the corresponding macroscopic behavior. Broader impacts of this work include improvement of fate and transport modeling, better practices for pesticide use and design, and an increased understanding of non-covalent interactions. These detailed studies will provide molecular level insights into how pollutants interact and associate with soils.

por.por_cntn:
Soils are essential to life on earth.  Over 95% of food consumed by modern societies come from cultivated soils and one of the key factors that allow soils to meet our food needs is the use of pesticides.  A more efficient use of pesticides that allows for more economic use and reduces any adverse effects requires a clear understanding of how pesticides interact with soils. The major soil component of interest is the organic matter component; however, from the chemical point of view, this component is an extremely complex and poorly-defined mixture that has greatly limited our molecular level understanding of how pesticides interact with (sorb to) soils. This project deconvoluted the complexity of soil organic matter component by creating engineered soil surrogates in which a mineral phase (silica beads or clays) were functionalized with short polymer chains, similar to how one deconstructs and then reconstructs a dish in modern cuisine. The chemical composition of the polymer chains was varied in terms of complexity, starting with a single block repeating molecular entities and progressing to up to three different blocks, each composed of a different repeating molecular entity. The chemical composition of the molecular entities was varied, with a focus on polarity and the length of the polymer chains as well as the order of the different blocks. These variations were designed to echo what is known of the organic matter component of real soils and to address a range of possible molecular level interactions between pesticides and this soil component known from the literature.  The pesticide sorption to these engineered soil surrogates was then analyzed. This analysis revealed that polarity as well as hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interactions, conformation, and pie-stacking strongly influence pesticide sorption to soils.

The project allowed for the cross-disciplinary training of a number of graduate and undergraduate students, especially in regards to the overall concept of the proposal's chemical approach.  The results have been and will continue to be presented to Dr. Cook's advanced undergraduate chemistry class. The engineered soil surrogates can be recycled and hence will provide a resource for future research, while the techniques, methods, and the molecular level insights yielded by this research have been and will continue to be utilized for a range of research projects in the PIs laboratories.
